skills.name: Find missing angles using angles around a point
Recognise the formula for circumference of a circle
Recognise the formula for area of a circle

explanations.A: The sum of the angles around the centre of a circle is 360⁰. This has been divided into 36 equal sectors so what will the angle of each sector be?
explanations.B: The sum of the angles around a point is 360⁰. Therefore, the sum of the angles around the centre of a circle is 360⁰. This 360⁰ has been divided into 36 equal pieces, as shown. Therefore, the angle of each sector is 360÷36=10⁰.
explanations.C: The sum of the angles around the centre of a circle is 360⁰. This has been divided into 36 equal sectors so what will the angle of each sector be?
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you had the right method, but thought there were 180⁰ in a circle. There are 180⁰ on a straight line. Can you remember how many degrees are around a point?

explanations.A: The sum of the angles around a point is 360⁰. Therefore, the sum of the angles around the centre of a dodecagon is 360⁰. This 360⁰ has been divided into 12 equal pieces, as shown. Therefore, the highlighted angle is 360÷12=30⁰
explanations.B: The sum of the angles around a point is 360⁰. Therefore, the sum of the angles around the centre of a dodecagon is 360⁰. How can we divide this into 12 equal pieces?
explanations.C: The sum of the angles around a point is 360⁰. Therefore, the sum of the angles around the centre of a dodecagon is 360⁰. How can we divide this into 12 equal pieces?
explanations.D: The sum of the angles around a point is 360⁰. Therefore, the sum of the angles around the centre of a dodecagon is 360⁰. How can we divide this into 12 equal pieces?

explanations.A: The circumference would be found by adding together all of the arcs of the sectors. What part of the circle does H represent?
explanations.B: I think you've found L! That would represent half the circumference. We are looking at H. What part of the circle does H represent?
explanations.C: Oo not quite! Think carefully about how those sectors would form a circle. Now try to draw on the length H.
explanations.D: If we imagine those sectors all forming a circle then H represents the length between the centre of the circle and each arc. H would therefore be approximately equal to the radius of the circle.

explanations.A: I think you've found B! That would represent the circumference. Look again at H. It is the combined widths of each band. What part of the circle would that represent?
explanations.B: Not quite. Look again at H. It is the combined widths of each band. What part of the circle would that represent?
explanations.C: Nearly! Try to imagine all the bands formed back into the circle. What length would H represent?
explanations.D: H is the combined width of each band. If we look at the circle we can see this is approximately equal to the radius of the circle.

explanations.A: I think you have assumed that L is the width of all of the sector arcs added together, when it is actually only 18 of them. What would that be equal to?
explanations.B: There is the arc length of 18/36 of the sectors lines up there to make L, which means it is half the circumference of the circle.
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the wrong part of the circle. ALL of the arcs of these sectors make up the distance around the edge of the circle. What do we call that?
explanations.D: I think you have chosen the wrong part of the circle. ALL of the arcs of these sectors make up the distance around the edge of the circle. What do we call that?

explanations.A: The outer most, and longest, band laid flat, would have the circumference of the circle as its length.
explanations.B: Not quite. Think about which band laid flat makes the base of the triangle.
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the wrong part of the circle. Think about which band laid flat makes the base of the triangle.
explanations.D: I think you have chosen the wrong part of the circle. Think about which band laid flat makes the base of the triangle.

explanations.A: I think you have used the formula for area. Remember that Circumference = 2πr
explanations.B: I think you have forgotten to halve your answer. Remember that C = 2πr
explanations.C: I think you have halved twice. Remember that Circumference = 2πr. What do we get when we halve it?
explanations.D: L is half the circumference. C = 2πr and half of that is just πr

explanations.A: I think you have used the formula for area. B is the length of the longest band. What part of a circle would this correspond to?
explanations.B: B is equal to the length of the longest band in the circle which would be the circumference.
explanations.C: Not quite. B is the length of the longest band. What part of a circle would this correspond to?
explanations.D: Not quite. B is the length of the longest band. What part of a circle would this correspond to?

explanations.A: The formula for the area of a circle is A = πr². You can see this from the diagram because we have an approximation of a rectangle where the length is πr (half of the circumference) and the height is r (the radius). So the area would be πr²
explanations.B: This is the formula for circumference, not area. Try to work out what parts of the circle L and H would represent in the diagram
explanations.C: Not quite. Try to work out what parts of the circle L and H would represent in the diagram and then use these to find an expression for the area
explanations.D: Nearly! Check what L and H represent carefully. L will be half of the circumference and H represents the radius. What do you get when you multiply these together?

explanations.A: The formula for the area of a circle is A = πr². You can see this from the diagram because the base of the triangle is the length of the longest strip (circumference) and the height tends towards the radius. To find the area of the triangle we would multiply these together and divide by 2. Giving us (2πr x r ) / 2 = πr²
explanations.B: This is the length of the longest strip (circumference). What other elements of the diagram could be used to get the area formula?
explanations.C: Not quite. Think about how the triangular diagram has been made. What do the length and height represent?
explanations.D: Not quite. Think about how the triangular diagram has been made. What do the length and height represent?
